batchMetadata.description: Advanced consolidation topics including intercompany transactions, push-down accounting, and complex structures

questions.question: Parent owns 80% of Subsidiary. During the year, Parent sold inventory to Subsidiary for $500,000 with a 25% gross profit margin. Subsidiary still holds 40% of this inventory at year-end. What intercompany profit must be eliminated in consolidation?
questions.explanation: Downstream sales (Parent to Sub) require full elimination of unrealized profit. Total profit = $500,000 × 25% = $125,000. Only the portion in ending inventory is unrealized: $125,000 × 40% = $50,000. This entire $50,000 is eliminated against consolidated net income. In downstream sales, 100% is eliminated against the parent's income (no NCI allocation).
questions.tip: Downstream sales: Unrealized profit = Total profit × % in ending inventory. 100% eliminated against parent's share (no NCI effect).

questions.question: Parent owns 70% of Subsidiary. Subsidiary sold inventory to Parent for $200,000 with a 30% gross profit. Parent sold all inventory to outside parties. What is the elimination of intercompany profit and its allocation?

options.B: $0 elimination; all inventory was sold externally
options.D: $60,000 elimination; $18,000 to parent, $42,000 to NCI

questions.explanation: No unrealized profit exists because all inventory was sold to outside parties. The profit has been realized through the external sale. Elimination entries are only needed for unrealized intercompany profits - profits on goods still held within the consolidated entity. Since none remains in ending inventory, there's nothing to eliminate.
questions.tip: Unrealized profit exists only in ending inventory. If all sold to third parties, profit is realized - no elimination needed.

questions.question: Parent sold equipment to its 100% owned Subsidiary for $300,000. The equipment had a book value of $200,000 and remaining life of 5 years. What is the elimination entry at end of Year 1?

options.A: Eliminate $100,000 gain; reduce depreciation expense by $20,000
options.B: Eliminate $100,000 gain only
options.C: Eliminate $80,000 gain; reduce depreciation expense by $20,000
options.D: No elimination needed for fixed assets

questions.explanation: Intercompany asset sales require elimination of unrealized gain and adjustment of excessive depreciation. Gain eliminated: $300,000 - $200,000 = $100,000. Subsidiary records depreciation on $300,000/5 = $60,000/year. Correct depreciation should be $200,000/5 = $40,000/year. Excess depreciation = $20,000. The adjustment reduces depreciation expense by $20,000 (realizes $20,000 of the gain).
questions.tip: Intercompany fixed asset sale: Eliminate gain + Reverse excess depreciation each year. Gain realizes over asset's remaining life.

questions.question: Parent acquires 75% of Subsidiary for $750,000. Subsidiary's identifiable net assets have fair value of $900,000. The fair value of NCI is $260,000. What is goodwill under the full goodwill method?
questions.explanation: Full goodwill method: Total acquisition value = Parent's consideration ($750,000) + Fair value of NCI ($260,000) = $1,010,000. Goodwill = Total value - Fair value of net assets = $1,010,000 - $900,000 = $110,000. Under partial goodwill: $750,000 - (75% × $900,000) = $750,000 - $675,000 = $75,000.
questions.tip: Full goodwill: Parent consideration + NCI FV - FV net assets. Partial goodwill: Parent consideration - Parent % × FV net assets.

questions.question: Parent owns 80% of Subsidiary. Subsidiary reports net income of $400,000, including $50,000 of unrealized upstream profit on inventory. What is NCI's share of Subsidiary's income?
questions.explanation: Upstream profits are allocated between parent and NCI based on ownership. Subsidiary's adjusted income = $400,000 - $50,000 unrealized profit = $350,000. NCI share = 20% × $350,000 = $70,000. The unrealized profit is shared: Parent 80% ($40,000), NCI 20% ($10,000). NCI's share is reduced by their portion of unrealized profit.
questions.tip: Upstream profit: Allocated to NCI proportionally. NCI income = NCI% × (Reported income - Unrealized profit).

questions.question: Parent acquires 100% of Subsidiary in a business combination. Under ASC 805, when may push-down accounting be applied in Subsidiary's separate financial statements?

options.A: Only when required by SEC for public companies
options.B: It is an accounting policy election available when substantially all ownership changes
options.C: Only when the subsidiary is liquidated
options.D: Never; fair value adjustments only appear in consolidated statements

questions.explanation: Under ASU 2014-17, push-down accounting is an election available when an acquirer obtains control of an entity. The acquired entity can elect to apply push-down accounting in its separate financial statements, restating assets and liabilities to fair value and recognizing goodwill. This is optional, not mandatory, and can be elected at the acquisition date.
questions.tip: Push-down: Optional election when substantially all ownership changes. Assets/liabilities restated to FV in subsidiary's own books.

questions.question: Company holds 30% of Target (equity method, $500,000 carrying value). Company acquires additional 50% for $900,000, gaining control. Fair value of the original 30% is now $540,000. Fair value of Target's net assets is $1,600,000. What gain is recognized on the previously held interest?
questions.explanation: When control is achieved in stages, the previously held equity interest is remeasured to fair value with gain/loss recognized in income. Gain = Fair value ($540,000) - Carrying value ($500,000) = $40,000. Total consideration for combination = Cash $900,000 + FV of prior interest $540,000 = $1,440,000. Goodwill or bargain purchase is then calculated from this total.
questions.tip: Step acquisition: Remeasure previously held interest to FV. Gain/loss = FV - Carrying value. Then combine with new consideration for total acquisition accounting.

questions.question: Parent owns 80% of Subsidiary and sells 35% of its interest, reducing ownership to 45%. What accounting treatment applies?

options.A: Continue consolidating; adjust NCI for ownership change
options.B: Deconsolidate; recognize gain or loss on disposal; apply equity method to retained interest
options.C: Continue consolidating but recognize gain on sale
options.D: Deconsolidate; continue carrying retained interest at book value

questions.explanation: When control is lost (ownership drops below 50%), deconsolidation occurs. The subsidiary is removed from consolidated statements. Parent recognizes a gain or loss equal to (proceeds received + fair value of retained interest) minus (carrying value of disposed interest). The retained 45% interest is then recorded at fair value and accounted for under the equity method.
questions.tip: Loss of control: Deconsolidate, recognize gain/loss (including FV remeasurement of retained interest), then apply appropriate method to remaining investment.

questions.question: Parent owns 80% of Subsidiary (800 shares of 1,000 outstanding). Subsidiary issues 250 new shares to outside investors at $50 per share (above book value of $40/share). Parent's carrying value was $32,000. What is the effect on Parent's investment and additional paid-in capital?

options.B: Investment decreases; charge to equity
options.D: Investment decreases; credit to APIC

questions.explanation: After issuance: 1,250 shares outstanding. Parent's 800 shares = 64% ownership (down from 80%). New subsidiary equity = Old equity ($40 × 1,000 = $40,000) + New proceeds ($50 × 250 = $12,500) = $52,500. Parent's share = 64% × $52,500 = $33,600. Increase from $32,000 to $33,600 = $1,600 gain, credited to APIC (equity transaction since control retained).
questions.tip: Subsidiary stock issuance (control retained): Change in parent's interest goes to equity (APIC), not income. Calculate new % ownership and share of new book value.

questions.question: Parent issued bonds with carrying value of $980,000 (including discount). Subsidiary purchases these bonds in the open market for $950,000. What is the constructive gain or loss on consolidation?

options.D: No gain or loss until bonds mature

questions.explanation: When one entity in a consolidated group acquires another entity's debt, it's treated as constructive retirement for consolidation purposes. Gain/loss = Carrying value of debt ($980,000) - Purchase price ($950,000) = $30,000 gain. This gain is eliminated in consolidation and recognized as a gain (debt extinguishment). In subsequent years, amortization of the intercompany investment and liability are also eliminated.
questions.tip: Intercompany bond acquisition: Constructive retirement. Gain/loss = Issuer's carrying value - Purchaser's cost. Recognized in period of acquisition.

questions.question: Parent acquires 100% of Target for $800,000. Target's identifiable net assets have fair value of $950,000. After reassessing all values, what is the accounting treatment?

options.B: Record gain on bargain purchase of $150,000 in income
options.D: Record extraordinary gain of $150,000

questions.explanation: When consideration transferred is less than fair value of net assets acquired, it's a bargain purchase. Under ASC 805, the acquirer must first reassess whether all assets and liabilities have been identified and properly valued. If the excess persists after reassessment, it's recognized as a gain in income (not extraordinary item - that classification was eliminated).
questions.tip: Bargain purchase: Reassess all values first. If FV of net assets still exceeds consideration, recognize gain in income immediately.

questions.question: Parent incurs $200,000 in finder's fees and $50,000 in legal fees directly related to acquiring a subsidiary. How are these costs treated?

options.B: Expensed as incurred
options.C: Added to the cost of investment
options.D: Deducted from additional paid-in capital

questions.explanation: Under ASC 805, acquisition-related costs such as finder's fees, advisory fees, legal fees, accounting fees, and other professional fees are expensed as incurred. They are not part of the consideration transferred and not added to goodwill. Only costs to issue debt or equity securities follow their respective standards (debt issuance costs amortized; equity issuance costs offset equity).
questions.tip: Acquisition costs: Expensed as incurred (except costs to issue securities). This changed from pooling/old purchase method.

questions.question: An acquisition agreement includes contingent consideration payable if Target achieves certain earnings targets. The fair value at acquisition is $100,000. What is the initial and subsequent accounting?

options.A: Record $100,000 liability; changes go to goodwill
options.B: Record $100,000 liability; changes go to income in subsequent periods
options.C: Do not record until contingency is resolved
options.D: Record as equity; no subsequent remeasurement

questions.explanation: Contingent consideration is recorded at fair value on the acquisition date as part of purchase price (liability or equity depending on terms). For contingent consideration classified as a liability, subsequent changes in fair value are recognized in earnings, not as adjustments to goodwill. Equity-classified contingent consideration is not remeasured.
questions.tip: Contingent consideration: Record at FV on acquisition date. Liability-classified: Remeasure through income. Equity-classified: No remeasurement.

questions.question: Parent acquires 100% of Subsidiary on April 1. Subsidiary's annual net income is $480,000, earned evenly throughout the year. How much of Subsidiary's income is included in consolidated net income for the year?
questions.explanation: Only income from the acquisition date forward is consolidated. April 1 through December 31 = 9 months. Consolidated income = $480,000 × (9/12) = $360,000. Pre-acquisition income ($120,000 for Jan-Mar) belongs to the former owners and is not included in consolidated results.
questions.tip: Midyear acquisition: Only post-acquisition income is consolidated. Pro-rate based on acquisition date.

questions.question: Six months after an acquisition, new information about a pre-existing contingency causes the acquirer to revise the acquisition-date fair value of a liability. How is this treated?

options.A: Adjust goodwill and the liability as of acquisition date
options.B: Recognize the change in current period income
options.D: No adjustment allowed after acquisition date

questions.explanation: The measurement period (maximum one year from acquisition) allows adjustments to provisional amounts recognized at acquisition. If new information relates to facts and circumstances existing at acquisition date, retrospective adjustments are made to goodwill and the related asset or liability. This is not an error correction but a refinement of provisional amounts.
questions.tip: Measurement period: Up to 1 year. New info about acquisition-date facts → Adjust goodwill retrospectively. After measurement period → Income statement.

questions.question: Company A has a variable interest in Entity X but is not the primary beneficiary. Company B is the primary beneficiary. How should Company A report its interest?

options.B: Use equity method regardless of ownership percentage
options.C: Apply appropriate GAAP based on nature of interest (could be cost, fair value, or equity method)
options.D: No recognition required

questions.explanation: Only the primary beneficiary consolidates a VIE. Other variable interest holders apply the accounting appropriate to their interest type: equity method if significant influence exists, fair value for certain investments, cost method for insignificant interests. The nature and terms of the specific variable interest determine the appropriate method.
questions.tip: VIE holder not primary beneficiary: Apply normal GAAP based on interest type. Equity method, FV, or cost depending on influence and characteristics.

questions.question: Subsidiary pays $100,000 in dividends to Parent (80% owner). What elimination entry is needed in consolidation?

options.B: Eliminate $80,000 dividend income; $20,000 to NCI
options.C: No elimination needed; dividends are cash transactions
options.D: Eliminate entire $100,000 and reduce retained earnings

questions.explanation: Parent records $80,000 dividend income (80% × $100,000). This must be eliminated because consolidated statements show only one entity - dividend payments between parent and subsidiary are internal. The $20,000 to NCI is a distribution to outside owners and reduces NCI balance on the consolidated balance sheet.
questions.tip: Intercompany dividends: Eliminate parent's share of dividend income. NCI's share reduces NCI balance (distribution to outsiders).

questions.question: At acquisition, Subsidiary's patents had book value of $200,000 and fair value of $500,000, with remaining life of 10 years. Two years after acquisition, what is the cumulative amortization adjustment for consolidation?
questions.explanation: Fair value adjustment = $500,000 - $200,000 = $300,000. Annual amortization of the adjustment = $300,000 / 10 years = $30,000. After 2 years, cumulative amortization = $30,000 × 2 = $60,000. This reduces the patent's carrying value in consolidation and is recognized as additional amortization expense each year.
questions.tip: FV adjustments on finite-life intangibles: Amortize the adjustment over remaining life. Track cumulative amortization for elimination entries.

questions.question: Subsidiary acquires 5% of Parent's outstanding stock in the open market. How is this treated in consolidation?

options.A: Subsidiary records investment; no consolidation adjustment
options.B: Treated as treasury stock by the consolidated entity
options.D: Recorded as a reduction of NCI

questions.explanation: When a subsidiary holds shares of the parent, from a consolidated perspective this is treasury stock - the consolidated entity effectively owns its own shares. The investment is eliminated and the parent shares held are reported as treasury stock in consolidated equity, reducing consolidated shareholders' equity.
questions.tip: Subsidiary owns parent stock: Treat as treasury stock in consolidation. Reduces consolidated equity.

questions.conceptTested: Subsidiary preferred stock held by outsiders
questions.question: Subsidiary has: Common stock owned 80% by Parent, Cumulative preferred stock (10%, $1,000,000 par) owned by outsiders. Subsidiary's net income is $200,000. What is NCI's share of income?
questions.explanation: NCI includes outside preferred shareholders (100%) and outside common shareholders (20%). Preferred dividends = 10% × $1,000,000 = $100,000 (all to NCI preferred holders). Income to common = $200,000 - $100,000 = $100,000. NCI share of common = $100,000 × 20% = $20,000. Total NCI share of income = $100,000 + $20,000 = $120,000.
questions.tip: Subsidiary preferred stock: First allocate preferred dividends, then divide remaining income between parent and NCI common. Preferred held by outsiders is part of NCI.

questions.question: A reporting unit has: carrying value $2,000,000 including goodwill of $300,000, fair value $1,850,000. What impairment loss is recognized?
questions.explanation: Under ASU 2017-04, goodwill impairment is the excess of carrying value over fair value, limited to the carrying amount of goodwill. Carrying value $2,000,000 - Fair value $1,850,000 = $150,000 implied impairment. Since this is less than goodwill ($300,000), impairment loss = $150,000. The two-step test was simplified to this one-step approach.
questions.tip: Goodwill impairment (simplified): Loss = Carrying value of unit - Fair value of unit, capped at goodwill amount.

questions.question: In a business combination, the target has in-process research and development valued at $2,000,000. How is this treated?

options.B: Capitalized as an indefinite-life intangible until project completed or abandoned
options.D: Capitalized and amortized over expected development period

questions.explanation: Under ASC 805, in-process R&D acquired in a business combination is capitalized as an intangible asset. It's treated as an indefinite-life intangible (not amortized, but tested for impairment) until the project is completed (then amortized over useful life) or abandoned (then impaired to zero).
questions.tip: IPR&D in acquisition: Capitalize. No amortization until project complete. Test for impairment annually until completion or abandonment.

questions.question: Parent sold land with book value of $150,000 to Subsidiary for $200,000. The land is still held by Subsidiary at year-end. What is eliminated in consolidation?

options.B: $50,000 gain and reduce land by $50,000
options.D: No elimination; land transaction is at arm's length

questions.explanation: Intercompany land sales are eliminated because no profit should be recognized on transactions within the consolidated entity. Eliminate the $50,000 gain from income and reduce land from $200,000 to $150,000 (original book value). Unlike depreciable assets, land doesn't 'realize' the gain through depreciation - it stays eliminated until sold to an outside party.
questions.tip: Intercompany land sale: Eliminate entire gain and reduce land to original book value. Unlike equipment, no annual realization through depreciation.

questions.question: Parent owns 80% of Subsidiary A. Subsidiary A owns 60% of Subsidiary B. What is Parent's effective ownership in Subsidiary B?
questions.explanation: Indirect ownership is calculated by multiplying ownership percentages: Parent's effective ownership in B = 80% × 60% = 48%. However, for consolidation purposes, both A and B are consolidated because Parent controls A, and A controls B (giving Parent indirect control). The 48% represents Parent's economic interest in B's income.
questions.tip: Indirect ownership: Multiply ownership chain. 80% × 60% = 48%. Control flows through chain, so B is consolidated if A is consolidated.

questions.question: A U.S. parent has a subsidiary in Japan. The subsidiary's sales are denominated in yen, expenses are in yen, and financing is from Japanese banks. What is likely the subsidiary's functional currency?

options.B: Japanese yen (local currency)
options.D: Determined solely by management election

questions.explanation: Functional currency is determined by the primary economic environment where the entity operates. Indicators include: currency of cash flows, sales prices, expenses, financing, and intercompany transactions. Since sales, expenses, and financing are in yen, the functional currency is likely the Japanese yen. This is based on economic factors, not management election.
questions.tip: Functional currency: Based on economic indicators (sales, costs, financing). Look at where entity primarily operates and transacts.

questions.question: A foreign subsidiary uses the local currency as its functional currency. Which translation method is used, and where are translation adjustments reported?

options.A: Temporal method; translation gain/loss in income
options.B: Current rate method; cumulative translation adjustment in OCI
options.C: Current rate method; translation gain/loss in income
options.D: Temporal method; cumulative translation adjustment in OCI

questions.explanation: When the functional currency is the local currency, the current rate method is used: assets and liabilities at current rate, revenues and expenses at average rate, equity at historical rates. The resulting translation adjustment is reported in other comprehensive income (OCI) as cumulative translation adjustment. This differs from remeasurement (temporal method) used when functional currency is USD.
questions.tip: Local functional currency: Current rate method → Translation adjustment to OCI. USD functional currency: Temporal method → Gain/loss to income.

questions.conceptTested: Changes in ownership without loss of control
questions.question: Parent owns 80% of Subsidiary and acquires an additional 10% from NCI shareholders for $150,000. Subsidiary's book value is $1,200,000. How is this transaction recorded?

options.A: Increase investment; recognize gain/loss on purchase
options.B: Record as equity transaction; adjust NCI and parent's equity
options.D: No entry needed in consolidated statements

questions.explanation: When a parent acquires additional shares from NCI while maintaining control, it's an equity transaction (no gain/loss recognition). The $150,000 payment is compared to the carrying amount of NCI acquired (10% × $1,200,000 = $120,000). The $30,000 difference reduces parent's equity (APIC or retained earnings). NCI balance is reduced by $120,000.
questions.tip: Additional shares acquired from NCI (control retained): Equity transaction. Difference between payment and NCI carrying value adjusts parent's equity.

questions.question: Parent decides to sell its 100% owned subsidiary, which represents a major strategic shift. How is the subsidiary reported while held for sale?

options.B: Continue consolidating; present results as discontinued operations if criteria met
options.C: Deconsolidate immediately upon decision to sell
options.D: Use equity method while held for sale

questions.explanation: Until actually sold, a subsidiary held for sale continues to be consolidated. If the disposal represents a strategic shift (major line of business, geographic area, or method of operations), the subsidiary's results are presented as discontinued operations in the consolidated income statement, shown separately from continuing operations.
questions.tip: Subsidiary held for sale: Continue consolidating. Discontinued operations presentation if strategic shift. Deconsolidate only when control actually lost.

questions.question: Parent charges Subsidiary $500,000 annually for management services. How is this treated in consolidation?

options.A: Report as management fee revenue and expense in consolidated statements
options.B: Eliminate the intercompany revenue and expense
options.C: Report as related party transaction only
options.D: Capitalize as part of subsidiary's operations

questions.explanation: Intercompany service fees are eliminated in consolidation just like intercompany sales. Parent's management fee revenue ($500,000) and Subsidiary's management fee expense ($500,000) are both eliminated. From a consolidated perspective, this is simply an internal allocation that doesn't affect the economic results of the combined entity.
questions.tip: Intercompany services: Eliminate revenue and expense. No net effect on consolidated income, but gross revenues and expenses are reduced.

questions.question: In acquiring a subsidiary, Parent identifies customer relationships (not previously recorded by Target) with estimated fair value of $400,000 and useful life of 10 years. How is this recorded?

options.B: Recognize as separate intangible asset and amortize
options.D: Recognize only if legally protected

questions.explanation: Customer relationships are an identifiable intangible asset separate from goodwill if they arise from contractual or other legal rights, OR if they are separable (can be sold, transferred, licensed, etc.). Customer relationships typically meet the contractual criterion or separability. They're recorded at fair value ($400,000) and amortized over their useful life (10 years).
questions.tip: Customer relationships acquired: Separate intangible if contractual/legal OR separable. Record at FV, amortize over useful life.

questions.conceptTested: Transactions between entities under common control
questions.question: Company A and Company B are both 100% owned by Parent Corp. Company A acquires Company B for $5,000,000 (B's book value is $4,000,000). How does Company A record the acquisition?

options.A: At fair value with goodwill of $1,000,000
options.B: At book value ($4,000,000) with $1,000,000 adjustment to equity
options.C: Using acquisition method at fair value
options.D: As a pooling of interests

questions.explanation: Transactions between entities under common control are typically recorded at predecessor carrying values (book value), not fair value. The excess of cash paid over book value is usually recorded as a reduction of equity (dividend or capital distribution). Acquisition method does not apply to common control transactions. Any difference between consideration and book value goes to equity.
questions.tip: Common control transactions: Use carryover (book) basis. No new goodwill. Difference from consideration = equity adjustment.

questions.conceptTested: Deferred taxes on fair value adjustments
questions.question: In an acquisition, Target's building has book value of $500,000 and fair value of $800,000. The tax rate is 25%. What deferred tax liability is recorded at acquisition?
questions.explanation: Fair value adjustments create book-tax differences. The building step-up of $300,000 ($800,000 - $500,000) creates a taxable temporary difference (book basis exceeds tax basis). Deferred tax liability = $300,000 × 25% = $75,000. This DTL is recorded at acquisition and increases goodwill or reduces bargain purchase gain.
questions.tip: FV adjustments: Create deferred taxes. Asset step-up = DTL. Asset write-down or liability step-up = DTA. Use acquisition-date tax rate.

questions.question: At year-end, Parent's investment in Subsidiary (under equity method on separate books) shows $500,000. Subsidiary's stockholders' equity totals $600,000. Parent owns 80%. What basic elimination entry is needed?

options.B: Eliminate investment $500,000, eliminate Sub's equity $600,000, establish NCI $120,000
options.D: Eliminate investment $480,000 (80% of equity)

questions.explanation: The basic elimination entry removes the investment account and the subsidiary's equity accounts, establishing NCI. Investment eliminated $500,000, Sub's equity eliminated $600,000, NCI established $120,000 (20% × $600,000). The $20,000 difference ($500,000 - 80% × $600,000) would be unamortized fair value adjustments or goodwill from original acquisition.
questions.tip: Basic elimination: Debit Sub's equity, Credit Investment, Credit NCI (NCI% × Sub's equity). Difference = FV adjustments/goodwill to track separately.

questions.question: A foreign subsidiary has the U.S. dollar as its functional currency. How are monetary assets translated, and where are exchange gains/losses reported?

options.A: At historical rates; gains/losses in OCI
options.B: At current rate; gains/losses in income
options.C: At current rate; gains/losses in OCI
options.D: At historical rates; gains/losses in income

questions.explanation: When USD is the functional currency, the temporal method (remeasurement) is used. Monetary assets and liabilities are remeasured at current exchange rates. Nonmonetary items use historical rates. Resulting remeasurement gains and losses are reported in current period income, not OCI.
questions.tip: Temporal method (USD functional): Monetary items at current rate, nonmonetary at historical. Gain/loss in income, not OCI.

questions.question: Small Company (legal acquirer) issues shares to acquire Large Company, but Large Company's former shareholders end up with 70% of combined entity's voting shares. Who is the accounting acquirer?

options.B: Large Company (accounting acquirer in reverse acquisition)
options.D: Neither; use pooling of interests

questions.explanation: This is a reverse acquisition. Although Small Company is the legal acquirer (it issued the shares), Large Company is the accounting acquirer because its former shareholders obtained majority voting control. Financial statements are prepared as if Large Company acquired Small Company. Large Company's assets/liabilities carry over at book value; Small Company's are fair valued.
questions.tip: Reverse acquisition: Legal acquirer issues shares, but target shareholders get majority control. Target is accounting acquirer. Assets of legal acquirer are fair valued.
